repnme.cdata!: India - Banking Sector Support Loan Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Banking Sector Support Loan Project
            for the Republic of India had satisfactory outcomes with low
            or negligible risk to development outcome performance by
            both the Bank and the borrower. The objective of the loan
            was to provide capital support to banks under support of the
            Government of India to enable them to maintain economic
            stimulus programs to contain the effects of the global
            crisis that began in 2008. The project was designed as a set
            of two development policy lending operations. The first was
            to provide budgetary support to the Government of India for
            capital injection before June 2010. The second loan in this
            program was expected to calibrate and reflect specific
            financing needs and include a program of policy and
            regulatory. The second loan did not materialize. However,
            despite the overall success of the design and the outcome,
            this assessment identified a number of issues, resulting in
            important lessons learned by the Bank in responding to its
            clients during periods of major crises. (1) Greater clarity
            in the project document was needed to underpin the second
            operation and loan. (2) The processing of the operation
            could have been more rapid; actual disbursement of funds
            happened a considerable time after the global crisis broke.
            (3) While arguments against the use of a deferred drawdown
            option are strong in retrospect, there should have been
            greater prior dialogue with the Government of India on
            crisis response.

11584694.majtheme: Economic management,Financial and private sector development

repnme.cdata!: India - Banking Sector Support Loan Program

abstracts.cdata!:
This program document presents the
            Banking Sector Support Loan (BSSL) in a set of two
            programmatic development policy loans (DPL) to the Republic
            of India. It responds to a request from the Government to
            provide financial support to enable the authorities to
            continue implementing their economic stimulus program, which
            is intended to contain the effects of the global economic
            crisis on the Indian economy. An important part of the
            overall stimulus program is the provision of capital support
            to public sector banks (PSB). This will help maintain the
            confidence of the public in the banking sector, prevent
            shortages of capital from leading to a slowdown in credit
            growth, and provide a capital buffer to public sector banks
            to absorb the possible increase in non-performing assets
            (NPA) resulting from the global financial crisis and its
            impact on India's economy. India's Gross Domestic
            Product (GDP) growth slowed from a peak 9.7 percent in
            2006-07 to about 5-6 percent in the third and fourth
            quarters of 2008-09, and is projected to remain in the
            5.5-6.5 percent range in 2009-10, a sharp drop with adverse
            implications for employment and poverty reduction, and on
            investment for long-term growth. The first BSSL will address
            needs arising from the current economic slowdown. Continued
            credit expansion by the banking system will complement the
            comprehensive stimulus measures that the Government has put
            in place since mid-2008, which include monetary, trade,
            fiscal, and financial sector actions, and will limit the
            slowdown before it becomes too deep.
